Look Im not saying you're wrong im just saying gillette must be careful because I've come to learn that society has a tendency of over simplifying complicated situations. Like part of the conversation should be females, girls and women alike should also stop making it okay for boys and men to behave the way they do. I always used to ask myself why the biggest assholes in school always had girlfriends. Everybody knew that these guys were up to no good but yet someone was always willing to date them and its kind off strange, its like being a up to no good made them quiet high in demand on the dating market. @teabear_c I It’s not my job or Gillette’s job to make individual men better people. That cake is baked. Men are whoever they’ve made themselves by the choices they make by time they need a razor. The second half of the add reminds us who’s watching. The boys. Boys are in trouble. They need guidance. They need role models. They need love and compassion to grow into men who don’t feed the beast. I’m not here to convince you to like or dislike that ad. It’s not about the ad ultimately. It’s not about gender PR. I’ve got a son I’m doing my best to raise and the greatest teacher I can be is to demonstrate by how I treat his mother, his sister, women I don’t know. I guess I’m too busy trying to make change than make noise.

@instayarde Yes i do believe we need the message but like i said there are ways that we can convey messages without making it seem like the whole idea of something is bad in this case masculinity is the something. Let me break down where I stand a lil but more. I believe men will always have a bad side just like women do, actually all people are capable of evil, now you throw something like bad parenting into the mix and you have a bad child who'll grow up to be a bad individual and even worse a bad member of society, you see what i did there i said bad parenting not toxic masculine fathers. My point is this, we cant as society go and highlight the evil that a group of people is capable of and make a whole ad out of it. People say bad things about the islam faith because of a minority of muslims who cause a lot of chaos in the world, for instance isis, and I believe the majority of people can agree that that's not what the islam faith is about. My point being it is wrong that gillitte is shinning masculinity in a bad light because of a group of bad men, the same way it is wrong that people shine the islam faith in a bad light because of groups like isis.
@instayarde sorry “woman” I admire. Here’s the link https://slate.com/human-interest/2019/01/gillette-commercial-toxic-masculinity-backlash.html

@instayarde this is from a Slate article from a man I admire. I’ve been an educator my entire adult life. And the answer isn’t boycotting or complaining. The answers lie in engaging and combating the narrative of men who are the problem and teaching the youth a better way.

@teabear_c This argument, of course, rests on the assumption that we need this message at all. Many of the ad’s critics think we don’t. But let me tell you: We do. The centerpiece of this ad isn’t grown men; it’s kids. The ad climaxes with footage of sweet-faced lads and the lesson “The boys watching today will be the men of tomorrow.” Gillette’s argument is that we need to be careful with the choices we make as adults because children learn decency and morality from us. As Slate’s science-based parenting columnist for the past six years—a job that has given me the opportunity to interview dozens of psychologists, social scientists, and pediatricians about the factors that shape child behavior and character—I agree passionately with this idea. Kids learn by watching what we do, not by listening to what we say, and boys in particular absorb a lot from their fathers as well as from male public figures. They watch prominent men in their lives stick up, or not, for victims of bullying or sexual harassment. They watch how men treat their girlfriends and wives and interact with women in public. Many boys watched one man, the president of the United States, publicly mock a woman who testified to Congress that she was a victim of sexual assault. Many also heard him brag about grabbing women “by the pussy.

@instayarde the problem I have with is ad is gillette decided to go and make it seem like the world is filled with the likes of scars and only scars, they left out the fact that there are simbas and mufasas who also fall victim to the ways of the likes of the scar archetype. The lion king a 20+ year old movie was able to convey a positive message yet still doing a very good job of highlighting the evil that people can bring into society. There are ways to convey messages correctly and then there is the way people are trying to do it today.

@victorialangguth I don’t know you. And you’ve clearly no idea who I am nor my experience or background. I don’t owe you any list of bonafides. But, as an adult and early childhood educator for twenty years and a male for fifty, your anecdotal tourism aside, The facts aren’t with you. Just days before the release of the ad, the American Psychological Association (APA) issued new "Guidelines for the Psychological Practice with Boys and Men." The new guidelines highlight the unique physical and mental health risks that boys and men face, including higher rates of completed suicide, violence, substance abuse, cardiovascular problems and early mortality. They also issue a warning against conforming to traditional stereotypes of masculinity, citing years of research that links machismo to the aforementioned health risks. Those are facts garnered by clinical studies with empirical evidence to back them up. The report states: "Socialization for conforming to traditional masculinity ideology has been shown to limit males' psychological development, constrain their behavior, result in gender role strain and gender role conflict (Pleck, 1981, 1995; O'Neil, 2008; O'Neil & Renzulli, 2013), and negatively influence mental health (e.g., O'Neil, 2008, 2013, 2015) and physical health (Courtenay, 2011; Gough & Robertson, 2017). Indeed, boys and men are overrepresented in a variety of psychological and social problems." Gillette hit the nail on the head.
@victorialangguth so you're saying that you support the bullying, harrassment and telling men to not show their feelings like the commercial showed SOME men do?
